newsitem.title: JAPAN: PRESS DIGEST - Top Japan business news - May 13.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Top Japan business news - May 13.

text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in the Japanese press on Tuesday, as reported by Kyodo news agency:
-- Government and ruling party eye cutting budget growth of "inevitable" costs, such as public-service personnel expenses and social security, by 600 billion yen in fiscal 1998/99.
-- Major trading houses plan to expand aircraft leasing business by purchasing Boeing B-737s.
-- Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd plans to raise long-term prime rate by 0.6 percentage point to 3.1 percent per annum.
-- Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko to visit Britain next year.
-- Japan's securities watchdog to file complaint against Nomura Securities Co Ltd for payoff scandal.
-- Jinnosuke Ashida, head of Japanese Trade Union Confederation (Rengo), to resign at end of current term in October.
-- Health and Welfare Ministry to legally control pet imports to prevent pet-transmitted diseases.
-- Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) reform panel to urge government to halt development corp's new financing for two large-scale projects in northern Japan.
-- Sumo tournament sees empty seats for first time since November, 1989.
